chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Migraine in pregnant or breastfeeding women
chapter.summary: Covers the management of pregnant or breastfeeding women with migraine.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Drugs for the prevention of migraine

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a woman with migraine who is pregnant or breastfeeding?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Carry out a thorough history and examination (see the CKS topic on Headache - assessment):
    • Be aware that new-onset migraine is rare in pregnant women, and pre-existing migraine usually improves.
    • Be alert for clinical features suggestive of serious secondary headache disorders requiring emergency or urgent referral to secondary care.
    • Always check blood pressure and urinalysis in addition to neurological examination.
  • For new-onset migraine:
    • It is essential to distinguish primary causes (such as migraine or tension headaches) from life-threatening secondary causes (such as pre-eclampsia and cerebral venous thrombosis).
    • Have a low threshold for seeking advice/referral.
  • If the woman has a history of migraine:
    • Ensure that characteristics of migraine before the pregnancy and current migraine have not altered and that the woman knows she must consult a health professional if headache is different from their usual migraine at any time pre or post-partum.
    • Have a low threshold for seeking advice/referral.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on Guidelines for all healthcare professionals in the diagnosis and management of migraine, tension-type, cluster and medication-overuse headache [BASH, 2010], Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015)], Primary care management of headache in adults [Becker, 2015] and Pharmacological management of migraine [SIGN, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Aube, 1999; MacGregor, 2012; Revell, 2014; Vetvik, 2017; Jarvis, 2018].

Migraine in pregnancy is quite unusual, with 50-75% of women experiencing improvement, 20% of whom experience complete resolution of symptoms.

Assessment
  • In addition to a full neurological examination, blood pressure and urinalysis must always be checked when assessing headache in pregnancy to help exclude secondary causes such as pre-eclampsia — any abnormalities require urgent assessment in secondary care [Revell, 2014; Jarvis, 2018].
New onset migraine
  • Migraine may occur in a small number of women for the first time during pregnancy. It is essential that serious secondary causes of headache (such as pre-eclampsia and cerebral venous thrombosis) are excluded before a diagnosis of migraine is made [Jarvis, 2018].
History of migraine
  • Women with menstrual related migraine and migraine without aura are most likely to have an improvement in symptoms (typically in the second and third trimesters) [Revell, 2014; UKTIS, 2016]  [Jarvis, 2018; SIGN, 2018].
  • Women with migraine with aura may have increased frequency of attacks or frequency may remain unchanged [Jarvis, 2018; SIGN, 2018].
  • Change in characteristics of pre-existing migraine in pregnancy requires urgent assessment in secondary care to exclude serious secondary causes of headache [Revell, 2014; Jarvis, 2018].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a pregnant or breastfeeding woman with migraine?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Provide information on migraine and self-care advice. Advise the woman that:
    • Migraine often improves in pregnancy, typically during the second and third trimesters.
    • Use of a headache diary can help identify triggers (such as lack of sleep, missed meals, and dehydration).
  • Where possible, try non-pharmacological measures (such as avoidance of triggers, relaxation techniques and cognitive behavioural therapy) before considering drug therapy.
    • Many drugs are contraindicated or have limited evidence of safety in pregnancy and breastfeeding.
    • If drug treatment is being considered, the woman must be made aware of the risks associated with each medication.
  • If drug treatment is essential, depending on contraindications and comorbidities:
    • Offer paracetamol first-line for the acute treatment of migraine in pregnancy and breastfeeding.
    • Consider ibuprofen (first and second trimesters only) or a triptan if paracetamol is ineffective.
      • There is less evidence of safety for nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) and triptans than for paracetamol.
      • NSAIDs should be avoided in the third trimester due to the risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus — refer to obstetrics if exposure to an NSAID occurs after the second trimester.
      • Sumatriptan is the preferred triptan in pregnancy and breastfeeding — seek specialist advice if unsure or the infant is pre-term, of low birth weight, or has other medical problems.
    • Do NOT prescribe aspirin or opiates for migraine in pregnant or breastfeeding women.
  • Arrange follow up (within 1 month), but ask the woman to seek urgent medical review sooner if they develop a headache that is different from their usual migraine or symptoms worsen.
    • Treatment options are limited in pregnancy — have a low threshold for referral.
  • Do NOT initiate preventive treatment in primary care for women who are pregnant or breastfeeding — seek specialist advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on Guidelines for all healthcare professionals in the diagnosis and management of migraine, tension-type, cluster and medication-overuse headache [BASH, 2010], Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015)], Primary care management of headache in adults [Becker, 2015] and Pharmacological management of migraine [SIGN, 2018], from the UK Teratology Information Service [UKTIS, 2016], the American Headache Society Position Statement On Integrating New Migraine Treatments Into Clinical Practice [American Headache Society, 2019] and expert opinion in review articles [Aube, 1999; MacGregor, 2012; Revell, 2014; Dodick, 2018; Jarvis, 2018].

Avoid drug treatment where possible

Clinical guidance from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015)] and the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) [SIGN, 2018] recommend that where possible pharmacological management of migraine in pregnancy should be avoided.

Improvement of migraine in pregnancy
  • Migraine usually improves during pregnancy (in about 50-75% of women) during the second and third trimesters. The normal rise in pregnancy hormones can stabilise migraine without aura but has been associated with increased frequency of migraine with aura [Jarvis, 2018; SIGN, 2018].
Acute treatment

If drug treatment cannot be avoided, the risks associated with use of each medication during pregnancy or breastfeeding must be discussed with the woman [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015); Revell, 2014; UKTIS, 2016; Dodick, 2018].

  • Paracetamol
    • Guidance from NICE [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015)], SIGN [SIGN, 2018], the UK Teratology Information Service [UKTIS, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles [Jarvis, 2018] agree that due to its safety profile, paracetamol is first choice for the short-term relief of acute migraine in pregnancy or breastfeeding. Regular use should be avoided.
  • NSAIDs
    • Guidance from NICE [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015)] and SIGN [SIGN, 2018] recommend ibuprofen (first and second trimesters only) as an alternative where paracetamol is ineffective for the short-term relief of acute migraine in pregnancy or breastfeeding.
    • There is less evidence of safety in pregnancy for NSAIDs than for paracetamol [UKTIS, 2016].
    • Regular use should be avoided [SIGN, 2018].
  • Triptans
    • There is less evidence of safety in pregnancy for triptans than for paracetamol [UKTIS, 2016].
    • Triptans are recommended as an option for treatment of acute migraine in pregnancy in NICE and SIGN guidance [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015); SIGN, 2018] — regular use should be avoided.
      • SIGN advise use of triptans only where treatment with paracetamol (all trimesters) or ibuprofen (first and second trimester only) has failed.
      • NICE considered 3 prospective cohort studies of triptans for migraine in pregnancy that reported a non-significant increased risk of several fetal adverse events. The Guideline Development Group agreed that the evidence reviewed did not indicate an increased risk associated with the use of triptans during pregnancy and added that evidence on safety of triptans in pregnancy was not conclusive but was reassuring [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015)].
    • The manufacturer recommends that [ABPI, 2019a]:
      • In pregnancy, sumatriptan should only be considered if the expected benefits to the mother is greater than any possible risk to the foetus.
      • In breastfeeding, infant exposure can be minimised by avoiding breast-feeding for 12 hours after treatment, during which time any breast milk expressed should be discarded.
  • Avoid aspirin and opiates
    • SIGN guidance states that aspirin, in doses for migraine, is not an analgesic of choice during pregnancy and should not be used in the third trimester of pregnancy [SIGN, 2018].
    • Aspirin should not be used in breastfeeding due to the risk of Reye’s syndrome [Joint Formulary Committee, 2019].
    • Opiates can exacerbate nausea and reduce gastric motility and are associated with medication overuse headache and dependence/abuse [Becker, 2015; Jarvis, 2018].
Preventative treatment
  • Preventive treatment for women who are pregnant or breastfeeding and those who are trying to conceive should not be initiated in primary care — many preventative drugs (such as topiramate) are contraindicated. Specialist input is required [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015); Becker, 2015; SIGN, 2018; American Headache Society, 2019].
Follow up

  • The recommendations on the follow up of migraine in adults are based on clinical guidelines [BASH, 2010; NICE, 2012 (updated 2015); Becker, 2015; SIGN, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Schwedt, 2014; Becker, 2015; Dodick, 2018].

    • Women with headache in pregnancy are at increased risk of serious secondary headache (such as pre-eclampsia and venous thrombosis) — a low threshold for seeking urgent advice/assessment in secondary care is essential [Jarvis, 2018].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a pregnant or breastfeeding woman?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Have a low threshold for seeking specialist advice or referring pregnant or breastfeeding woman with migraine as:
    • There is an increased risk of serious secondary causes of headache.
    • Treatment options for migraine in pregnancy and breastfeeding are limited.
  • Consider admission or urgent referral if:
    • A serious cause of headache is suspected (for further information, see the CKS topic on Headache - assessment).
    • The person is in severe, uncontrolled status migrainosus (migraine lasting for more than 72 hours).
  • Seek advice/refer to neurology (with urgency depending on the clinical situation) if:
    • Diagnosis of migraine is uncertain.
    • A complication of migraine has developed (for example migraine has become chronic).
    • Atypical symptoms (such as motor weakness or poor balance) are present.
    • Treatment in primary care does not adequately control the symptoms.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on when to refer a pregnant or breastfeeding woman with migraine are based on the clinical guidelines Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2012 (updated 2015)], Primary care management of headache in adults [Becker, 2015] and Pharmacological management of migraine [SIGN, 2018] and expert opinion in a narrative reviews [Revell, 2014; Jarvis, 2018].
